political_factors.factor_name: BNetzA extends 800/1800/2600 MHz spectrum by 5 years
political_factors.current_status: BNetzA decided to extend 800MHz, 1800MHz, and 2600MHz spectrum usage rights by 5 years (originally expiring end of 2025). Conditions: 99.5% national area coverage ≥50Mbps by 2030; 99% of households in sparsely populated municipalities ≥100Mbps by 2029. All three operators must negotiate spectrum sharing with MVNOs/service providers. Special requirement: all three must provide 800MHz 2×5MHz shared access to 1&1; O2 must continue leasing 2600MHz 2×10MHz to 1&1. Re-auction expected in 2029.
political_factors.trend: BNetzA decided to extend 800MHz, 1800MHz, and 2600MHz spectrum usage rights by 5 years (originally expiring end of 2025). Conditions: 99.5% national area coverage ≥50Mbps by 2030; 99% of households in sparsely populated municipalities ≥100Mbps by 2029. All three operators must negotiate spectrum sharing with MVNOs/service providers. political_factors.factor_name: German government launches €1.2B Gigabit Funding Programme 2025
political_factors.current_status: German Federal Ministry for Digital and Transport launches the 2025 Gigabit Funding Programme, allocating €1.2B for fiber infrastructure. Targets: 50% household FTTH/FTTB coverage by 2025, 100% fiber coverage by 2030. Fiber connections grew over 20% YoY.
political_factors.trend: German Federal Ministry for Digital and Transport launches the 2025 Gigabit Funding Programme, allocating €1.2B for fiber infrastructure. Targets: 50% household FTTH/FTTB coverage by 2025, 100% fiber coverage by 2030. Fiber connections grew over 20% YoY.
political_factors.industry_impact: German Federal Ministry for Digital and Transport launches the 2025 Gigabit Funding Programme, allocating €1.2B for fiber infrastructure. Targets: 50% household FTTH/FTTB coverage by 2025, 100% fiber coverage by 2030. Fiber connections grew over 20% YoY.
political_factors.company_impact: German government launches €1.2B Gigabit Funding Programme 2025: may create new market access or subsidy opportunities for vodafone_germany

political_factors.current_status: From July 1, 2024, landlords can no longer include cable TV fees in ancillary costs (Nebenkostenprivileg abolished). Vodafone most affected: originally 8.5M MDU subscribers, retention rate ~50% (~4M retained). Fixed-line service revenue declined 5.9% in H1 FY25. By Q3 FY26, fixed-line decline narrowed to -1.1%, headwind easing.
political_factors.trend: From July 1, 2024, landlords can no longer include cable TV fees in ancillary costs (Nebenkostenprivileg abolished). Vodafone most affected: originally 8.5M MDU subscribers, retention rate ~50% (~4M retained). Fixed-line service revenue declined 5.9% in H1 FY25. By Q3 FY26, fixed-line decline narrowed to -1.1%, headwind easing.

By Q3 FY26, fixed-line decline narrowed to -1.1%, headwind easing.

Inflation affects both OPEX (energy, wages) and consumer willingness to pay

society_factors.company_impact: Fiber migration presents both investment challenge and growth opportunity for vodafone_germany

technology_factors.industry_impact: 5G enables network slicing, enterprise services, and FWA -- new revenue streams
technology_factors.company_impact: 5G network capabilities are key competitive differentiator for vodafone_germany

technology_factors.trend: Fiber deployment accelerating as DSL/copper nears end of life
technology_factors.industry_impact: Fiber replaces copper/cable as the fixed broadband standard, requiring massive CAPEX
technology_factors.company_impact: Fiber strategy (build vs buy vs partner) is a critical decision for vodafone_germany

technology_factors.factor_name: Vodafone restructures cable TV frequencies nationwide
technology_factors.current_status: Vodafone begins nationwide cable network frequency restructuring, creating unified spectrum and releasing broadband capacity. Technical upgrade covers 400+ cities and 8.6M TV connections, expected completion mid-2026. Goal: free up spectrum resources for faster broadband speeds.
technology_factors.trend: Vodafone begins nationwide cable network frequency restructuring, creating unified spectrum and releasing broadband capacity. Technical upgrade covers 400+ cities and 8.6M TV connections, expected completion mid-2026. Goal: free up spectrum resources for faster broadband speeds.
technology_factors.industry_impact: Vodafone begins nationwide cable network frequency restructuring, creating unified spectrum and releasing broadband capacity. Technical upgrade covers 400+ cities and 8.6M TV connections, expected completion mid-2026. Goal: free up spectrum resources for faster broadband speeds.
technology_factors.company_impact: Vodafone restructures cable TV frequencies nationwide strengthens vodafone_germany competitive position and market presence

technology_factors.factor_name: Vodafone-Altice FibreCo JV: FTTH to 7M homes in 6 years
technology_factors.current_status: Vodafone and Altice formed FibreCo JV to deploy FTTH to 7M homes over 6 years. 80% upgrading within Vodafone's existing cable footprint, 20% greenfield expansion. Simultaneously advancing cable upgrades: node splitting + DOCSIS 3.1 high-split (3Gbps) → DOCSIS 4.0 (10Gbps). This is Vodafone's core strategic move in transitioning from cable to fiber.
technology_factors.trend: Vodafone and Altice formed FibreCo JV to deploy FTTH to 7M homes over 6 years. 80% upgrading within Vodafone's existing cable footprint, 20% greenfield expansion. new_business_models: FWA (Fixed Wireless Access) as fiber alternative

AI/ML for network optimization and customer experience

value_transfer_trends: Value shifting from voice/SMS to data and digital services
B2B/ICT growing faster than consumer segment
Fiber displacing copper and cable broadband
trends.key_message: Macro environment: Favorable. Key opportunities: Regulatory Environment, National Digital Strategy. Key risks: Regulatory Environment, Nebenkostenprivileg (MDU cable TV bundling) abolished Industry is mature. (+0.3% YoY (CQ2_2025 -> CQ4_2025))

changes.description: Vodafone completes 1&1 customer migration: 12M users on network
changes.impact_description: Vodafone successfully completed the 1&1 customer migration; 12M 1&1 customers now on Vodafone's nationwide 5G network. This is one of the largest customer migrations in European telecom history. Wholesale revenue contribution expected to reach full run-rate by Q4 FY26. Network test results continue to improve; migration did not affect network quality.

changes.description: 1&1 completes OpenRAN migration, reaches 25% own network coverage
changes.impact_description: All 1&1 mobile subscribers have migrated to its own OpenRAN 5G network (first in Europe). Approximately 1,500 own base stations operational, ~4,500 under construction. Achieved the 25% population coverage regulatory deadline target. Q3 2025 mobile net adds +40K (H1 roughly flat due to migration impact). 9-month CAPEX €228.7M primarily for network build-out.

Vodafone completed the acquisition of Skaylink (€175M, EV/EBITDA 7.0x), gaining 500+ cloud and security specialists. Skaylink specializes in AWS/Azure deployment, migration, and AI solutions. New B2B head Hagen Rickmann targets: €1B additional enterprise revenue over 5 years. This is a key step in Vodafone Business's transformation from connectivity to digital services.

changes.description: Deutsche Telekom Q3 2025: revenue +1.5%, net profit +14.3%
changes.impact_description: DT Q3 2025 group revenue €28.935B (+1.5% YoY), EBITDAaL margin 38.2%. Net profit grew 14.3% to €2.67B. YTD free cash flow +6.8% to €16.1B. Germany Q4 outlook: EBITDA growth >2%, benefiting from cost savings and easing wage/energy pressure. Q4 2025 full results scheduled for February 26, 2026.

changes.description: Vodafone restructures cable TV frequencies nationwide
changes.impact_description: Vodafone begins nationwide cable network frequency restructuring, creating unified spectrum and releasing broadband capacity. Technical upgrade covers 400+ cities and 8.6M TV connections, expected completion mid-2026. Goal: free up spectrum resources for faster broadband speeds.

changes.description: DT reboots fibre tactics, targets Vodafone cable footprint
changes.impact_description: DT adjusts its fiber strategy, actively deploying FTTH in Vodafone cable coverage areas, directly competing with Vodafone's cable+fiber hybrid network. This is DT's offensive strategy leveraging fiber first-mover advantage to capture Vodafone fixed-line customers.

changes.description: O2 Germany Q2 2025: revenue -2.4% but IoT +47%, users growing
changes.impact_description: O2 Q2 2025 total revenue declined 2.4% (mobile service revenue -3.4%), but subscriber growth was strong: Q2 contract customers +184K. IoT connections grew 47% YoY (Q2 net adds 177K), the biggest highlight. 5G coverage at 98%, leading the industry. EBITDA margin stable at ~30.6%.

changes.description: Vodafone-Altice FibreCo JV: FTTH to 7M homes in 6 years
changes.impact_description: Vodafone and Altice formed FibreCo JV to deploy FTTH to 7M homes over 6 years. 80% upgrading within Vodafone's existing cable footprint, 20% greenfield expansion. Simultaneously advancing cable upgrades: node splitting + DOCSIS 3.1 high-split (3Gbps) → DOCSIS 4.0 (10Gbps). This is Vodafone's core strategic move in transitioning from cable to fiber.

changes.description: German telecom market reaches $86B, CAGR 5.53% to 2030
changes.impact_description: VATM 26th market analysis report: German telecom market 2025 size $86B (~€79B annually), projected to reach $112.6B by 2030, CAGR 5.53%. Market has 150+ service providers, highly competitive. Industry-average ARPU declining ~4%. Mobile data service revenue CAGR 9.5%, 5G plans are the main growth engine. Fiber connections grew over 20%, 97% household broadband coverage.

changes.description: BNetzA extends 800/1800/2600 MHz spectrum by 5 years
changes.impact_description: BNetzA decided to extend 800MHz, 1800MHz, and 2600MHz spectrum usage rights by 5 years (originally expiring end of 2025). Conditions: 99.5% national area coverage ≥50Mbps by 2030; 99% of households in sparsely populated municipalities ≥100Mbps by 2029. All three operators must negotiate spectrum sharing with MVNOs/service providers. Special requirement: all three must provide 800MHz 2×5MHz shared access to 1&1; O2 must continue leasing 2600MHz 2×10MHz to 1&1. Re-auction expected in 2029.

Lack of digital-native sub-brands across operators

market_customer.customer_value_migration: Value migration is mixed: some segments trending up while price-sensitive segments face pressure. Differentiated strategy by segment recommended.
market_customer.key_message: Germany telecom market totals EUR 12.3B in quarterly revenue; competitive strengths in Availability, Assurances; Market outlook is favorable with more opportunities than threats.

key_factors.name: Number of competitors
key_factors.description: 4 active operators in the market

key_factors.name: Market concentration
key_factors.description: Top operator holds 50% of market revenue (total: EUR 12.3B)

key_factors.name: Growth rate disparity
key_factors.description: Service revenue growth ranges from -3.4% to +1.1% (spread: 4.5pp)

key_factors.name: Margin pressure
key_factors.description: Average EBITDA margin: 30.8%

implications: Market is concentrated with top player at 50% revenue share.

key_factors.name: Active new entrant: 1&1 AG
key_factors.description: 1&1 AG is currently building/expanding its network presence

key_factors.name: 1&1 completes OpenRAN migration, reaches 25% own network coverage
key_factors.description: All 1&1 mobile subscribers have migrated to its own OpenRAN 5G network (first in Europe). Approximately 1,500 own base stations operational, ~4,500 under construction. Achieved the 25% population coverage regulatory deadline target. Q3 2025 mobile net adds +40K (H1 roughly flat due to migration impact). 9-month CAPEX €228.7M primarily for network build-out.

key_factors.name: Entry barriers
key_factors.description: High barriers: spectrum licensing, massive capex for network build, regulatory approvals, established brand loyalty

implications: 1&1 AG entering the market may increase competitive pressure on pricing and coverage.
High entry barriers (spectrum, capex, regulation) limit new competitors, but determined entrants with deep pockets can still disrupt.

key_factors.name: OTT messaging replaces SMS/voice
key_factors.description: WhatsApp, Signal, Teams replacing traditional voice/SMS revenue. OTT messaging penetration continues to grow.

key_factors.name: Streaming replaces linear TV/IPTV
key_factors.description: Netflix, Disney+, YouTube Premium substituting traditional TV/cable TV subscriptions.

key_factors.name: Wi-Fi offload reduces cellular dependency
key_factors.description: Public and private Wi-Fi networks reduce reliance on mobile data, especially in urban areas.

key_factors.name: Cloud services substitute enterprise ICT
key_factors.description: AWS, Azure, GCP offering direct enterprise connectivity, reducing operator B2B ICT revenue opportunity.

implications: OTT services continue to erode traditional voice/SMS revenue; operators must pivot toward data, connectivity, and digital services.
Streaming substitution pressures TV/IPTV bundling strategies; operators should focus on aggregation and super-bundling.

key_factors.name: Network equipment vendor concentration
key_factors.description: Oligopoly of 3 major vendors (Huawei, Ericsson, Nokia). Limited alternatives increase supplier leverage on pricing and technology roadmaps.

key_factors.name: Semiconductor supply chain
key_factors.description: Chip supply constraints can create bottlenecks for both network equipment and consumer devices.

key_factors.name: Tower infrastructure
key_factors.description: Independent tower companies (e.g., Vantage Towers, GD Towers) have pricing power for site rentals and co-location.

key_factors.name: Fiber infrastructure suppliers
key_factors.description: Fiber cable and deployment contractors influence capex for FTTH rollout programs.

implications: Vendor oligopoly limits negotiation leverage; multi-vendor strategies and Open RAN initiatives can help diversify supply.
Tower company independence increases site rental costs; operators should evaluate infrastructure-sharing arrangements.

key_factors.name: Consumer churn rates
key_factors.description: Average mobile churn: 0.93%/month. Highest: 1.05% indicating moderate willingness to switch.

key_factors.name: Postpaid contract mix
key_factors.description: Average postpaid ratio: 69%. Moderate contract lock-in moderately constrains buyer mobility.

key_factors.name: Individual consumer bargaining power
key_factors.description: Individual consumers have low bargaining power, but low switching costs (number portability, short contracts) mean they vote with their feet.

key_factors.name: Enterprise customer concentration
key_factors.description: Large enterprise customers have significant bargaining power through multi-vendor strategies and competitive tenders.

key_factors.name: Regulatory protection for buyers
key_factors.description: EU regulations support number portability, contract transparency, and maximum contract lengths, enhancing consumer switching ability.

implications: Enterprise customers can leverage multi-vendor strategies; differentiation through service quality and SLAs is critical.
Low switching costs and regulatory support for portability mean operators must compete on value, not lock-in.

telefonica_o2.growth_strategy: Margin optimization / cost transformation; subscriber acquisition focus; 5G network leadership
telefonica_o2.supply_chain_status: Primary vendor: Nokia + Samsung; 55% virtualized; 5G SA: Commercial since 2025-03; Core: Nokia
telefonica_o2.business_model: Mobile-centric with fixed complement; service-revenue dominant; moderate-margin profile
telefonica_o2.org_structure: CTO: Mallik Rao (Telefónica Group); CFO: Markus Rolle (Finance veteran); CEO: Markus Haas (CFO O2 Germany)
telefonica_o2.talent_culture: 3 C-suite leaders; transitioning to digital culture
likely_future_actions: Telefonica O2 Germany may pursue cost optimization or strategic pivot given declining revenue trend.
Telefonica O2 Germany is likely to continue market share expansion in mobile, leveraging positive subscriber momentum.
Telefonica O2 Germany with 98% 5G coverage is positioned to push 5G monetization through premium tiers and B2B use cases.

implications.description: Telefonica O2 Germany is weak in: Enterprise Solutions, Product Innovation. Target can differentiate in these dimensions.
implications.suggested_action: Invest in Enterprise Solutions, Product Innovation to capture customers dissatisfied with Telefonica O2 Germany.

implications.description: Telefonica O2 Germany excels in: 5G Deployment, Network Coverage, Pricing Competitiveness. Study their approach for best practices.
implications.suggested_action: Benchmark Telefonica O2 Germany's practices in 5G Deployment, Network Coverage, Pricing Competitiveness.

implications.description: Telefonica O2 Germany has 98% 5G coverage, creating potential network advantage.
implications.suggested_action: Accelerate 5G deployment to close coverage gap.

deutsche_telekom.growth_strategy: Revenue-led profitable growth; subscriber acquisition focus; strong B2B/enterprise push; 5G network leadership
deutsche_telekom.supply_chain_status: Primary vendor: Ericsson + Huawei (legacy); 70% virtualized; 5G SA: Commercial since 2024-09; Core: Ericsson + Nokia
deutsche_telekom.business_model: Mobile-centric with fixed complement; service-revenue dominant; high-margin profile
deutsche_telekom.org_structure: CEO: Srini Gopalan (DT Board, Consumer); CFO: Christian Illek (McKinsey partner); CTO: Claudia Nemat (Tech/Innovation)
likely_future_actions: Deutsche Telekom is likely to continue aggressive network expansion (capex/revenue at 19% with growing revenue).
Deutsche Telekom is likely to continue market share expansion in mobile, leveraging positive subscriber momentum.
Deutsche Telekom with 97% 5G coverage is positioned to push 5G monetization through premium tiers and B2B use cases.

implications.description: Deutsche Telekom's growing revenue indicates competitive pressure; they are capturing market value.
Deutsche Telekom is weak in: Pricing Competitiveness. Target can differentiate in these dimensions.
implications.suggested_action: Invest in Pricing Competitiveness to capture customers dissatisfied with Deutsche Telekom.

implications.description: Deutsche Telekom excels in: 5G Deployment, Brand Strength, Customer Service. Study their approach for best practices.
implications.suggested_action: Benchmark Deutsche Telekom's practices in 5G Deployment, Brand Strength, Customer Service.

implications.description: Deutsche Telekom has 97% 5G coverage, creating potential network advantage.
implications.suggested_action: Accelerate 5G deployment to close coverage gap.

one_and_one.growth_strategy: Market share expansion (investing for growth); subscriber acquisition focus
one_and_one.supply_chain_status: Primary vendor: OpenRAN (Rakuten Symphony); 100% virtualized; 5G SA: Commercial, OpenRAN first-mover; Core: Mavenir (cloud-native)
one_and_one.business_model: Convergent (mobile + fixed); service-revenue dominant; low-margin / scale-focused
one_and_one.org_structure: CTO: Karsten Pradel (Network expert); CFO: Markus Huhn (United Internet); CEO: Ralph Dommermuth (Founder)
one_and_one.talent_culture: 3 C-suite leaders; transitioning to digital culture
likely_future_actions: 1&1 AG is likely to continue aggressive network expansion (capex/revenue at 39% with growing revenue).
1&1 AG is likely to continue market share expansion in mobile, leveraging positive subscriber momentum.
1&1 AG may accelerate fiber migration or FWA push to counter broadband subscriber losses.
1&1 AG as a new entrant will likely focus on network buildout, aggressive pricing, and customer acquisition.
1&1 AG will need significant network investment (coverage score: 45/100).

implications.description: 1&1 AG's growing revenue indicates competitive pressure; they are capturing market value.
1&1 AG is weak in: 5G Deployment, Brand Strength, Digital Services. Target can differentiate in these dimensions.
implications.suggested_action: Invest in 5G Deployment, Brand Strength, Digital Services to capture customers dissatisfied with 1&1 AG.

implications.description: 1&1 AG excels in: Pricing Competitiveness. Study their approach for best practices.
implications.suggested_action: Benchmark 1&1 AG's practices in Pricing Competitiveness.

competition.competitive_landscape: The market comprises 4 active operators: Telefonica O2 Germany, Vodafone Germany, Deutsche Telekom, 1&1 AG. Overall competition intensity is assessed as medium. Revenue ranking: Deutsche Telekom (6,200M), Vodafone Germany (3,092M), Telefonica O2 Germany (2,000M), 1&1 AG (1,035M). Five Forces: Existing Competitors: high; New Entrants: medium; Substitutes: high; Supplier Power: medium; Buyer Power: medium.
competition.key_message: In a 4-player market with medium competition intensity, Deutsche Telekom leads with 50% revenue share. Target operator holds 25% share. Strongest competitive force: Existing Competitors.

controlled_vs_resale.summary: Fully owned cable-HFC network (largest in Germany ~24M homes passed); fiber via JV with Altice (FibreConnect); mobile own-network. ~95% self-built infrastructure, ~5% wholesale/resale.

recent_tech_initiatives: Vodafone restructures cable TV frequencies nationwide
evolution_strategy.summary: DOCSIS 3.1→4.0 cable upgrade path for 1 Gbps+; parallel FTTH deployment via FibreConnect JV targeting 7M homes by 2028; 5G NSA rollout on 3.6 GHz.

network.vs_competitors: 5G: behind Telefonica O2 Germany by 6pp; Fiber: 1.9x more homepass than Telefonica O2 Germany; 5G: behind Deutsche Telekom by 5pp; Fiber: 5.7x less homepass than Deutsche Telekom
network.b2b_impact: Edge computing: 12 nodes; IoT connections: 3000K; B2B revenue share: 17%
network.cost_impact: High capex intensity (25.9%); Dual fixed-network cost (fiber + cable)

customer_perception.summary: Customer Service -4pp vs market; Brand Strength +4pp vs market; Pricing Competitiveness -6pp vs market

self_analysis.org_culture: Stable leadership team (avg tenure >3 years); Growth-oriented strategic posture; High-investment posture; Transformation-oriented culture under Vodafone Group direction; customer-centricity push via NPS programs; agile transformation in digital operations; German engineering tradition meets UK group culture.
self_analysis.performance_gap: Top performance gaps: EBITDA margin gap: -5.9pp vs leader (Deutsche Telekom at 42.1%); Revenue share gap: -25.2pp vs leader (50.3%); 5G Deployment: -19pp vs leader
self_analysis.opportunity_gap: Top opportunity gaps: FTTH migration upside (fiber only 6% of homepass footprint); B2B revenue gap (58% below market leader)
self_analysis.strategic_review: Management outlook: Germany EBITDA: H2 performing better than H1, but FY26 will not return to positive growth.. Revenue trajectory growing, margins strong (36.2%). Execution momentum positive — strengths outweigh weaknesses. Primary risk: Customer Service: score 70 (market avg 74)

management_commentary.content: Vodafone Business Germany service revenue declined 1.8% in Q3 (Q2: -1.6%), widening decline. Reason: ARPU pressure on mobile contract renewals + core connectivity business under sustained pressure. Highlight: strong digital services demand. Skaylink acquisition (completed December 2025) expected to accelerate growth in cloud, security, and managed services. New B2B head Hagen Rickmann's 5-year €1B growth target is a key strategic commitment.
management_commentary.speaker: Management

management_commentary.content: Broadband pricing strategy: another price increase in January 2026, adopting a 'more-for-more' approach. Fixed-line consumer revenue has stabilized. New customer broadband ARPU at a 3-year high (+21% YoY). Q4 volume trends expected to be similar, but the value equation is working. Retail pricing actions between March and October 2025 are supporting the ARPU trend.
management_commentary.speaker: Management

management_commentary.content: Mobile service revenue grew 2.8% in Q3 (Q2: 3.8%), growth decelerating. Reason: wholesale revenue growth partially offset by ARPU pressure and service provider payment timing. Post-1&1 migration, network test results continue to improve — 12M user migration is one of Europe's largest ever. Consumer contract customer net adds 42,000 (Q2 only +1,000), consumer momentum improving.
management_commentary.speaker: Management

management_commentary.content: Germany EBITDA: H2 performing better than H1, but FY26 will not return to positive growth. Key tailwinds: (1) MDU YoY base effect starting to fade from Q3; (2) 1&1 wholesale revenue reaching full run-rate by Q4; (3) MVNO base effects. Positive EBITDA growth not expected until FY27.
management_commentary.speaker: Management

management_commentary.content: Group FY26 guidance reaffirmed at upper end: EBITDAaL €11.3-11.6B, free cash flow €2.4-2.6B. YTD EBITDAaL grew 5.3% to €8.5B, in line with expectations. Group service revenue grew 5.4% in Q3. November 2025: FY26 dividend per share increased 2.5%, reflecting medium-term free cash flow growth confidence.
management_commentary.speaker: Management

exposure_points.trigger_action: 1&1 building own mobile network and migrating users off Vodafone wholesale
exposure_points.side_effect: Loss of wholesale revenue as 1&1 users migrate to own network
exposure_points.attack_vector: 1&1 positions as independent operator with competitive pricing

exposure_points.trigger_action: Heavy reliance on cable (DOCSIS) technology while market shifts to fiber
exposure_points.side_effect: Technology perception gap as competitors lead fiber deployment
exposure_points.attack_vector: DT markets fiber superiority; cable seen as legacy

exposure_points.trigger_action: Low fiber penetration compared to Deutsche Telekom
exposure_points.attack_vector: Customers migrating to FTTH offerings from DT
evidence: Fiber subscriber base significantly smaller than cable

self_analysis.key_message: Ranked #2 of 4 operators in market; revenue EUR 3,092M; EBITDA margin 36.2%; stable but facing challenges; key strength: Brand Strength; key challenge: Customer Service; Management outlook: Germany EBITDA: H2 performing better than H1, but FY26 will not return to positive growth. Key tailwinds: (1) MDU YoY base effect starting to fade from Q3; (2) 1&1 wholesale revenue reaching full run-rate by Q4; (3) MVNO base effects.

weaknesses: Loss of wholesale revenue as 1&1 users migrate to own network
Technology perception gap as competitors lead fiber deployment
